newsitem.title: USA: Rubbermaid buys Graco; stock plunges on profit warning.
newsitem.headline: Rubbermaid buys Graco; stock plunges on profit warning.

text.p: Rubbermaid Inc. said Wednesday it agreed to buy Graco Children's Products Inc. for $320 million in cash, but Rubbermaid's stock fell after it warned that its earnings for the latest quarter will be flat.

The Wooster, Ohio-based maker of plastic and rubber products, said it was buying Graco, a manufacturer of infant strollers, portable play yards, and other infant products, from a privately owned group of investors.

News of the acquisition of Elverson, Pa.-based Graco, failed to spark enthusiasm for Rubbermaid's stock, which plunged $3.50 to $23 on the New York Stock Exchange, after the company said its third-quarter sales and earnings per share will be comparable with a year-ago.
In last year's third quarter, Rubbermaid earned 32 cents a share, or $50.3 million on sales of $641.5 million.
"People were expecting that the quarter could be up 15 to 20 percent," said Eric Bosshard of Midwest Research-Maxus Group.
Continued softness in the sales of large, outdoor juvenile products will offset gains in other parts of the company, Rubbermaid said.
The company said a jump of more than 50 percent in the cost of plastic resin -- the raw material used in making plastics -- had hurt Rubbermaid's results.

"Despite significant gains in lowering our cost structure, higher costs for resin and lower-than-expected unit volume will prevent us from continuing to attain the growth in profitability we had been expecting this year," said Chairman and Chief Executive Wolfgang Schmitt.
Analysts said Rubbermaid was acquiring Graco in an effort to limit its dependence on plastic and to diversify its raw material base.
"They are so reliant on this one raw material and its been obvious that resin costs have been going against them," said Eric Bosshard, an analyst at Midwest Rsearch-Maxus Group.
Another analyst who did not want to be identified said he had anticipated Rubbermaid's third quarter sales to rise about 6 percent from a year-ago.
Analysts said the impact of higher resin prices is likely to carry into the fourth quarter, which typically is weaker than the third quarter.
